The **Horsehead Nebula** (also known as **Barnard 33**) is a [dark
nebula](/wiki/Dark_nebula "Dark nebula") in the constellation
[Orion](/wiki/Orion_\(constellation\) "Orion \(constellation\)").[1] The
nebula is located just to the south of the star [Alnitak](/wiki/Zeta_Orionis
"Zeta Orionis"), which is farthest east on Orion's Belt, and is part of the
much larger [Orion Molecular Cloud
Complex](/wiki/Orion_Molecular_Cloud_Complex "Orion Molecular Cloud Complex").
The nebula was first recorded in 1888 by [Scottish](/wiki/Scotland "Scotland")
astronomer [Williamina Fleming](/wiki/Williamina_Fleming "Williamina Fleming")
on photographic plate B2312 taken at the [Harvard
College](/wiki/Harvard_College "Harvard College") Observatory.[2] The
Horsehead Nebula is approximately 1500 [light years](/wiki/Light_year "Light
year") from Earth. It is one of the most identifiable nebulae because of the
shape of its swirling cloud of dark dust and gases, which bears some
resemblance to a [horse](/wiki/Horse "Horse")'s head when viewed from
Earth.[3]

## Overview[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Horsehead_Nebula&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Overview")]

The dark cloud of dust and gas is a region in the Orion Molecular Cloud
Complex where star formation is taking place. It is located in the
constellation of [Orion](/wiki/Orion_\(constellation\) "Orion
\(constellation\)"), which is prominent in the winter evening sky in the
Northern Hemisphere and the summer evening sky in the Southern Hemisphere.
This [stellar nursery](/wiki/Stellar_nursery "Stellar nursery"), as it is
known, can contain over 100 known kinds of organic and inorganic gases as well
as dust; some of the latter is made up of large and complex organic
molecules.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The red or pinkish glow originates from [hydrogen](/wiki/Hydrogen "Hydrogen")
gas predominantly behind the nebula, ionized by the nearby bright star [Sigma
Orionis](/wiki/Sigma_Orionis "Sigma Orionis"). [Magnetic
fields](/wiki/Magnetic_field "Magnetic field") channel the gases leaving the
nebula into streams, shown as streaks in the background glow.[4] A glowing
strip of hydrogen gas marks the edge of the massive cloud, and the densities
of nearby stars are noticeably different on either side.

The heavy concentrations of dust in the Horsehead Nebula region and
neighbouring Orion Nebula are localized, resulting in alternating sections of
nearly complete opacity and transparency.[5] The darkness of the Horsehead is
caused mostly by thick dust blocking the light of stars behind it.[6] The
lower part of the Horsehead's neck casts a shadow to the left.[7] The visible
dark nebula emerging from the gaseous complex is an active site of the
formation of "low-mass" stars. Bright spots in the Horsehead Nebula's base are
young stars just in the process of forming. It has a magnitude of
.11.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]
